Let $g(k)$ be the smallest integer (if any such exists) such that any $g(k)$ points in $\mathbb{R}^2$ contains an empty convex $k$-gon (i.e. with no point in the interior). Does $g(k)$ exist? If so, estimate $g(k)$.



A variant of the 'happy ending' problem [107], which asks for the same without the 'no point in the interior' restriction. Erd\H{o}s observed $g(4)=5$ (as with the happy ending problem) but Harborth \cite{Ha78} showed $g(5)=10$. Nicol\'{a}s \cite{Ni07} and Gerken \cite{Ge08} independently showed that $g(6)$ exists. Horton \cite{Ho83} showed that $g(n)$ does not exist for $n\geq 7$.

Heule and Scheucher \cite{HeSc24} have proved that $g(6)=30$.

This problem is #2 in Ramsey Theory in the graphs problem collection.




References


[Ge08] Gerken, Tobias, Empty convex hexagons in planar point sets. Discrete Comput. Geom. (2008), 239-272.

[Ha78] Harborth, Heiko, Konvexe F\"{u}nfecke in ebenen Punktmengen. Elem. Math. (1978), 116-118.

[HeSc24] M. Heule and M. Scheucher, Happy Ending: An Empty Hexagon in Every Set of $30$ Points. Tools and Algorithms for the Construction and Analysis of Systems, Lecture Notes in Computer Science (2024), 61-80.

[Ho83] Horton, J. D., Sets with no empty convex 7-gons. Canad. Math. Bull. (1983), 482-484.

[Ni07] Nicol\'{a}s, Carlos M., The empty hexagon theorem. Discrete Comput. Geom. (2007), 389-397.
